conclusion: Analyzing if the pedestrian can catch the bus using the v-t graph
The pedestrian is moving at a constant speed of 8 m/s, represented by a horizontal line on the graph
The bus starts from rest at the origin and accelerates uniformly, represented by a diagonal line
The bus's velocity increases linearly with time
The bus's acceleration is calculated as 1 m/s² from the v-t graph
Initially, the pedestrian is 36 meters away from the bus, moving at a constant 8 m/s, and the bus starts from rest and accelerates at 1 m/s²
The pedestrian's position over time is given by xₚ(t) = -36 + 8t
The bus's position over time is given by xᵦ(t) = 0.5t²
To determine if they meet, set xₚ(t) = xᵦ(t) resulting in the equation 0.5t² - 8t + 36 = 0
Using the quadratic formula, the equation has no real solutions due to a negative value under the square root
The pedestrian cannot catch up with the bus as there are no real solutions to the equation
Physically, the bus's acceleration allows it to eventually outpace the pedestrian permanently
